response.answer_text: Download our buyers guide to learn about VoIP Phone System at your own pace: VoIP System Guide - VoIP Supply What exactly is a VoIP phone system? You use your phone system (also known as a PBX) every day, so you already know that phone systems are responsible for handling your call control and managing your connection to your telephone service provider. What you might not be familiar with is VoIP. VoIP is short for Voice over Internet Protocol. VoIP is a way to make calls across your Local Area Network (LAN) and or Wide Area Network (WAN). The technology behind VoIP converts your analog voice into digital packets which are then sent across a network using the Internet Protocol (IP) to their end destination. VoIP is most commonly associated with making calls across the Internet. As you've probably guessed, a VoIP phone system gets connected to your LAN. It uses your LAN as the backbone of the system – connecting your VoIP phones and your VoIP service provider to the VoIP PBX. That makes a VoIP phone system a phone system that uses IP technology to handle your call control and manage your connection to the Wide Area Network over which your VoIP service comes. Even though a VoIP phone system uses VoIP and is connected to your LAN most systems can connect directly to the Publicly Switched Telephone Network (PSTN). This gives you the ability to use both VoIP and the PSTN for your calling. If your head is spinning right now, don't worry. Reading about the differences between your existing PBX and a VoIP phone system should help. How is a VoIP phone system different from your existing PBX? A VoIP phone system is quite the change from your existing PBX. Your existing PBX uses TDM technology. A VoIP phone system uses IP technology.Your existing PBX uses its own closed network. A VoIP phone system uses your existing LAN.Your existing PBX uses the PSTN for dial tone. A VoIP phone system uses a VoIP service provider and or the PSTN for dial tone.Despite using a different technology, network and primary voice service, what makes a VoIP phone system truly different is its ability to easily integrate with your other business systems. This integration of systems allows you to increase productivity, efficiency and sales. When's the last time you said that about your existing PBX? There we go getting a little ahead of ourselves again (sorry). It's true that there are numerous benefits you will receive when you purchase a VoIP phone system. But before we get to those, how about we check out what a VoIP phone system offers?

Image Source and Credit: Integral Choice Gone are the days of wired phones and handsets. Today we can make phone calls anytime, anywhere from a device connected to the Internet. VoIP means Voice over IP (Internet Protocol). VoIP is the technology that converts our voice into a digital signal, this enables the user to make calls directly from a computer, a phone, or any internet-connected devices. In simple words, VoIP means phone service delivered over the internet. It is a very useful method for making calls. They are much cheaper than the calls made on normal phone lines. One can easily call and speak to anyone across the globe without having to worry about paying additional charges for international calls. A VoIP phone system could be: A phone and a VoIP adapter – With the help of a special VoIP adapter, one can make VoIP calls from a regular landline phone. These adapters are required to be plugged into either a phone socket or in the internet router. A computer – Programs like Skype, Google Talk, Apple Face Time allow you to make voice calls to anyone who also has installed the same program or app. Few programs like Skype can also be used to call on a regular landline or mobile numbers too but at an additional cost. If both the parties have the program, calling between them is free of cost. A Smartphone or Tablet/Ipad – You can make VoIP calls using your Smartphone or Tablet by installing apps like Skype, WhatsApp, Facebook Messenger, Viber, etc.
